title: Epic 6: Unit System
description: Unit stats (HP, attack, defense, speed, range, LOS), unit types (Villager, Infantry, Archer, Cavalry, Siege, Naval), production queues, upgrades, formations.

title: Unit stats: HP, attack, defense, speed, range, LOS
description: Define unit stat model: HP (hit points), Attack (base damage), Defense (damage reduction), Speed (tiles/sec), Range (attack range in tiles), LOS (line of sight radius). Stats loaded from data files.

title: Unit types: Villager, Infantry, Archer, Cavalry, Siege, Naval
description: Implement unit categories: Villager (gathers, builds), Infantry (melee, slow, armored), Archer (ranged, fragile), Cavalry (fast melee, bonus vs archers), Siege (slow, anti-building), Naval (water-only). Each with base stats.

title: Unit production from buildings with queue
description: Buildings produce units: select building, click unit icon, unit added to queue. Queue shows up to 5 units. Production takes time and costs resources (deducted on queue). Units spawn at rally point.

title: Unit upgrades via tech tree
description: Tech tree unlocks unit upgrades: +attack, +defense, +range, +speed. Upgrades apply globally to all existing and future units of that type. Research at specific buildings (Blacksmith, Library, etc.).

title: Formation movement
description: Basic formation support: line, box, staggered. Selected group maintains formation shape when moving. Units adjust speed to stay in formation. Default formation is staggered.

title: Epic 2: Core Game Loop
description: Isometric camera, unit selection, movement with pathfinding, right-click commands, game clock and speed controls.

title: Isometric camera with pan, zoom, edge-scroll
description: Implement Camera2D with: WASD/arrow key panning, mouse wheel zoom (min/max limits), edge-of-screen scrolling, middle-mouse drag pan. Camera should work with isometric coordinate system.

title: Unit selection: click, box-select, control groups
description: Left-click to select single unit, click-drag for box selection, Shift+click to add/remove from selection, Ctrl+number to set control group, number key to recall group. Selection highlight/indicator on units.

title: Unit movement with A* pathfinding on isometric grid
description: Implement A* pathfinding on isometric tile grid. Right-click to move selected units. Handle terrain obstacles, unit collision avoidance. Use Godot's AStarGrid2D or custom implementation suited to iso grid.

title: Right-click context commands
description: Right-click context-sensitive commands: move to empty ground, attack enemy unit, gather from resource node, build/repair building. Show appropriate cursor for each action.

title: Game clock and pause/speed controls
description: Game timer with pause (Space), normal speed, fast (2x), very fast (3x). Display game time in HUD. All game logic should use game delta time, not real time.

title: ADR-008: Art Pipeline — Isometric Asset Production Strategy
description:
Defines the visual production pipeline for all game assets: tiles, units, buildings, UI elements, effects. This is the single highest-risk bottleneck for a solo/small team building an isometric RTS. Every decision here has compounding downstream effects — tile dimensions determine map scale, sprite resolution determines animation cost, and art method determines total throughput.

DECISION

1. Tile geometry: 128x64px diamond tiles (2:1 ratio). Elevation step: 32px vertical offset per level (half tile height). This gives 3 usable elevation levels within reasonable sprite heights.

2. Sprite scale contract:
   - Villager: ~48px tall (standing), fits within one tile footprint
   - Infantry/military: ~52-56px tall
   - Cavalry/mounted: ~64px tall
   - Buildings (1x1): 128x128px max (one tile footprint, extends above tile)
   - Buildings (2x2): 256x192px max (four tile footprint)
   - Buildings (3x3): 384x256px max (Town Center, Wonder)
   - Trees/resources: ~64-80px tall, single tile footprint

3. Animation budget per unit type:
   - Idle: 4 frames x 8 directions = 32 frames
   - Walk: 8 frames x 8 directions = 64 frames
   - Attack: 6 frames x 8 directions = 48 frames
   - Death: 6 frames x 1 direction (mirrored) = 6 frames
   - Gather (villager only, per resource type): 6 frames x 4 directions = 24 frames x 4 = 96 frames
   - Total per military unit: ~150 frames
   - Total for villager: ~230 frames (most expensive unit)
   Buildings: idle (1-2 frames), construction (4 stages), destruction (3 stages), no directional variants.

4. Art production method: Hybrid pipeline.
   - Phase 1 (prototype): Colored geometric shapes. Diamonds for tiles, circles for units, rectangles for buildings. Distinct colors per type. Zero art skill required. Gets the game playable immediately.
   - Phase 2 (alpha): AI-generated base sprites (Stable Diffusion / DALL-E / Midjourney) with manual cleanup in Aseprite. Generate isometric renders, hand-clean edges, ensure palette consistency. Fastest path to "looks like a game."
   - Phase 3 (polish): Hand-pixel or commission professional sprites for hero units, unique buildings, and UI. Replace AI bases where quality falls short.
   This phased approach means art never blocks engineering. Gameplay is always testable with current-phase art.

5. Color palette: 5 palettes — one per age cluster.
   - Stone/Bronze Age: earthy browns, muted greens, terracotta
   - Iron/Medieval Age: deeper greens, grays, stone blues, banners with civ colors
   - Industrial Age: brick reds, iron grays, smoke, amber
   - Information/Singularity Age: steel blues, white, neon accents, holographic highlights
   Each civ has a primary + secondary color applied to units and building banners (not full recoloring — just team markers).

6. Tileset scope (minimum viable for map gen):
   - 5 base terrain types: grass, forest floor, desert/sand, shallow water, deep water
   - Per terrain: center tile + 8 edge transitions to each adjacent type = massive combinatorial explosion
   - Solution: Use Godot 4 TileMap terrain autotiling. Define terrain peering bits. Need ~15-20 tile variants per terrain type to cover edges, corners, and inner corners.
   - Total base tileset: ~80-100 tile variants for 5 terrains
   - Mountain/cliff tiles: separate layer, ~20 variants
   - Elevation transitions: ~12 variants (ramp up, ramp down, cliff edge per cardinal direction)
   - Grand total tileset: ~120 tiles minimum viable

7. Asset file organization:
   - assets/sprites/units/{civ}/{unit_name}/ — spritesheet per unit
   - assets/sprites/buildings/{civ}/{building_name}/ — spritesheet per building
   - assets/tiles/terrain/ — tileset textures
   - assets/tiles/elevation/ — elevation tiles
   - assets/ui/ — UI elements, icons, fonts
   - assets/effects/ — particle textures, projectiles
   - assets/audio/ — sound effects, music (future)
   Naming convention: snake_case, descriptive. E.g., villager_walk_se_03.png

8. Spritesheet format: Pack all directional frames into a single spritesheet per animation. Use Godot SpriteFrames resource for animation definitions. Aseprite as the source-of-truth editor (exports to PNG spritesheet + JSON metadata).

CONSEQUENCES

- Phased art approach means engineering is never blocked by art production
- Geometric placeholders are ugly but functional — game is always playable
- AI-assisted middle phase dramatically accelerates asset production (10x vs hand-drawing)
- 128x64 tile size is generous enough for detail but small enough to fit large maps on screen
- Animation budget is realistic (~150 frames/unit) — not cutting corners but not AAA
- The tileset scope (~120 tiles) is the first major art investment and should be prioritized
- Sprite scale contract prevents the "everything is the wrong size" problem that kills isometric games
- 8-direction sprites are industry standard for isometric; 4 directions looks cheap, 16 is overkill

title: Epic 9: AI Opponents
description: AI personality types (aggressive, economic, balanced), resource gathering, base building, military production, tech progression, difficulty scaling.

title: AI personality types: aggressive, economic, balanced
description: Define AI personalities that affect decision weights: Aggressive (early military, frequent attacks), Economic (fast expansion, late military), Balanced (mixed approach). Personality chosen at game start.

title: AI resource gathering and base building
description: AI manages villagers: assigns to resource gathering with good ratios, builds houses for population, builds resource drop-offs near nodes, expands base with production buildings. Uses simple priority system.

title: AI military production and attack timing
description: AI produces military units based on personality. Builds army to threshold then attacks. Aggressive AI attacks earlier with smaller armies. Targets enemy economy and production buildings. Retreats when outnumbered.

title: AI tech progression and age advancement
description: AI researches technologies and advances ages. Economic AI prioritizes age advancement. Aggressive AI prioritizes military upgrades. AI follows a predefined tech order per personality per age.

title: AI difficulty scaling
description: Difficulty levels: Easy (slower decisions, no resource bonus), Normal (standard), Hard (+20% gather rate, faster decisions), Expert (+50% gather rate, optimal build orders). Difficulty chosen at game start.

title: ADR-006: Project Structure
description: Godot 4 project layout: scenes/ (by feature), scripts/ (GDScript), assets/ (art, audio, fonts), autoloads/ (singletons: GameManager, ResourceManager), data/ (JSON: tech trees, unit stats, civ data).

title: Epic 4: Resource System
description: 5 core resources (Food, Wood, Stone, Gold, Knowledge), villager gathering, resource depletion/regeneration, resource UI, trade mechanics.

title: Define 5 core resources: Food, Wood, Stone, Gold, Knowledge
description: Create resource data model with 5 types: Food, Wood, Stone, Gold, Knowledge. Each player has a stockpile. Resources are integers. Knowledge is a unique resource earned from Libraries and research.

title: Villager gathering mechanics
description: Villagers: right-click resource node to gather. Walk to node, harvest animation (timed), carry resources back to nearest drop-off (Town Center, Mill, Mining Camp, Lumber Camp). Carry capacity limit. Repeat cycle.

title: Resource depletion and regeneration
description: Resource nodes have finite amounts that deplete with gathering. Trees regrow slowly. Berry bushes deplete permanently. Gold/stone mines deplete permanently. Fish deplete slowly. Show remaining amount on hover.

title: Resource UI display (top bar)
description: Top-of-screen resource bar showing: Food, Wood, Stone, Gold, Knowledge amounts. Also show population (current/cap). Update in real-time. Icons for each resource type.

title: Trade and market mechanics
description: Market building allows converting between resources at exchange rates. Trade carts between own markets and allied/neutral markets for gold income. Rates fluctuate based on supply/demand. Available from Bronze Age.

title: Epic 5: Building System
description: Building placement with ghost preview, construction process, core buildings (Town Center, House, Farm, Barracks, etc.), HP/destruction, population cap.

title: Building placement with ghost preview
description: Select building from build menu, show translucent ghost on cursor following isometric grid. Green = valid placement, red = invalid (blocked by terrain, other buildings, or resources). Click to place.

title: Construction process with villager builders
description: After placement, building appears as foundation. Villager walks to site and builds over time (progress bar). Multiple villagers speed up construction. Building not functional until complete.

title: Core buildings: Town Center, House, Farm, Barracks, Dock, Market, Library, Wonder
description: Implement core building types with stats: Town Center (villager production, drop-off, pop+5), House (pop+5), Farm (food source), Barracks (military units), Dock (ships), Market (trade), Library (research/knowledge), Wonder (win condition). Each has cost, build time, HP.

title: Building HP, destruction, and ruins
description: Buildings have HP. Take damage from attacks. Show damage states (intact, damaged, critical). When destroyed, leave ruins tile that can be built over. Destroyed buildings free population cap.

title: Population cap tied to houses
description: Each House adds +5 population cap. Town Center adds +5. Maximum population cap of 200. Cannot produce units when at cap. Display current/max in resource bar.

title: Epic 1: Project Foundation
description: Set up Godot 4 project with folder structure, export presets, CI pipeline, and placeholder asset pipeline.

title: Set up Godot 4 project with folder structure
description: Initialize Godot 4.x project. Create directory structure: scenes/, scripts/, assets/, autoloads/, data/. Configure project.godot with window settings for isometric view.

title: Configure export presets for macOS and Windows
description: Set up Godot export templates for macOS (.dmg/.app) and Windows (.exe). Test export builds run on both platforms.

title: Set up CI build pipeline with GitHub Actions
description: Create GitHub Actions workflow that builds Godot project for macOS and Windows on push. Use official Godot Docker image or headless export.
close_reason: Superseded by dedicated Quality Pipeline epic with comprehensive CI stories

title: Create placeholder asset pipeline
description: Create placeholder sprites for terrain tiles (128x64 iso), basic unit sprite, basic building sprite. Set up tileset resource. Establish asset naming conventions.
close_reason: Superseded by expanded art pipeline stories under dedicated epic

title: Epic 1c: Art Pipeline & Visual Foundation
description: Establish the complete art production pipeline before gameplay epics begin. Lock in tile geometry, sprite scale, animation budgets, color palettes, and production method. Produce the Phase 1 geometric placeholder tileset so map generation and gameplay can be developed and tested immediately. Build alongside Epic 1 and 1b — art decisions cannot wait until after CI is done.

title: Create Phase 1 geometric placeholder tileset (5 terrains)
description:
Create the minimum viable tileset using colored geometric shapes — no art skill required. This is Phase 1 art that gets the game playable immediately.

Tiles needed (128x64px diamond iso):
- Grass: green diamond
- Forest floor: dark green diamond with small triangle trees
- Desert/sand: tan/yellow diamond
- Shallow water: light blue diamond with simple wave pattern
- Deep water: dark blue diamond

For each terrain, create:
- Center tile (1 variant)
- Edge transitions using Godot 4 TileMap terrain autotiling peering bits
- At minimum: 4 cardinal edges + 4 corner pieces per terrain pair
- Use solid color fills with 1px darker border lines to distinguish tiles

Also create:
- Mountain/cliff placeholder: gray triangles on tile
- Elevation ramp placeholder: angled gradient tile
- Resource node placeholders: colored circles (gold=yellow, stone=gray, wood=brown, food=red)

Configure Godot TileSet resource with:
- Isometric tile size 128x64
- Terrain sets defined with autotile peering
- Physics layers for walkability (water=impassable, mountain=impassable)

Target: ~40-60 placeholder tiles that let map generation produce a visually distinguishable map.

Acceptance criteria:
- TileSet resource loads in Godot editor without errors
- All 5 terrain types visually distinct at game zoom level
- Terrain autotiling produces reasonable transitions
- Resource nodes distinguishable from terrain

title: Create Phase 1 geometric placeholder unit sprites
description:
Create placeholder unit sprites using colored geometric shapes. These are functional stand-ins that make the game testable without real art.

Units needed:
- Villager: small colored circle (~24px diameter) with player color fill, tiny direction indicator (triangle arrow showing facing)
- Infantry: slightly larger circle with square shield icon
- Archer: circle with line indicating range
- Cavalry: oval (elongated, suggesting mounted)
- Siege: large rectangle
- Naval/ship: diamond shape (wider than tall)

For each unit create:
- 8-direction facing variants (N, NE, E, SE, S, SW, W, NW) — can be the same circle with a rotated direction arrow
- Idle: 1 frame per direction (just the shape)
- Walk: 2 frames per direction (alternate slight offset for bounce effect)
- Attack: 2 frames per direction (shape + flash)
- Death: 3 frames (shrink to nothing)

Player colors: Player 1 = blue, Player 2 = red, Player 3 = green, Player 4 = yellow. Applied as fill color.

Selection indicator: green circle outline drawn beneath selected units.

Configure as Godot SpriteFrames resources with named animations (idle_n, idle_ne, walk_s, attack_e, etc.).

Acceptance criteria:
- All unit types visually distinct from each other at game zoom
- Direction of movement/facing is clear
- Player ownership is immediately obvious via color
- SpriteFrames resources load and animate in editor preview

title: Create Phase 1 geometric placeholder building sprites
description:
Create placeholder building sprites using colored geometric shapes.

Buildings needed (all use player color as accent):
- Town Center (3x3 tiles): large rectangle with flag, ~384x256px
- House (1x1): small square, ~128x128px
- Farm (2x2): green rectangle with grid lines, ~256x192px
- Barracks (2x2): rectangle with crossed swords icon, ~256x192px
- Dock (2x1): rectangle extending onto water tile
- Market (2x2): rectangle with coin icon
- Library (2x2): rectangle with book icon
- Wonder (4x4): large distinctive shape, ~512x320px
- Mill (1x1): resource drop-off for food
- Mining Camp (1x1): resource drop-off for gold/stone
- Lumber Camp (1x1): resource drop-off for wood

For each building create:
- Complete state: solid shape with icon and player color banner
- Construction stages: 4 frames (foundation outline → 25% → 50% → 75%, then complete replaces)
- Damaged state: same shape with red tint overlay at <50% HP
- Ruins: gray/dark outline of original shape (shown after destruction)

Ghost placement preview: semi-transparent version (green for valid, red for invalid).

Acceptance criteria:
- Each building type immediately recognizable by shape and icon
- Building footprint matches tile grid (1x1, 2x2, 3x3, 4x4)
- Construction progression is visually clear
- Player color visible on all buildings

title: Establish asset directory structure and naming conventions
description:
Create the asset directory tree and document naming conventions before any assets are committed.

Directory structure:
- assets/sprites/units/placeholder/ — Phase 1 geometric units
- assets/sprites/units/{civ}/ — Per-civ unit art (future phases)
- assets/sprites/buildings/placeholder/ — Phase 1 geometric buildings
- assets/sprites/buildings/{civ}/ — Per-civ buildings (future phases)
- assets/tiles/terrain/ — Tileset textures
- assets/tiles/elevation/ — Elevation and cliff tiles
- assets/tiles/transitions/ — Terrain transition tiles
- assets/ui/icons/ — Resource icons, button icons
- assets/ui/panels/ — HUD panel backgrounds
- assets/ui/fonts/ — Game fonts
- assets/effects/ — Particle textures, projectiles
- assets/portraits/ — Unit/building portrait art for info panel

Naming convention (document in assets/README.md):
- All snake_case, lowercase
- Units: {unit_name}_{animation}_{direction}_{frame}.png (e.g., villager_walk_se_03.png)
- Spritesheets: {unit_name}_{animation}_sheet.png (packed)
- Buildings: {building_name}_{state}.png (e.g., town_center_complete.png, barracks_construction_02.png)
- Tiles: {terrain}_{variant}_{index}.png (e.g., grass_center_01.png, grass_edge_n_01.png)
- UI: {element}_{state}.png (e.g., button_normal.png, button_pressed.png)

Also create:
- assets/.gdignore for any source files (Aseprite .ase) that shouldn't be imported
- Godot import presets: pixel art (no filtering, no mipmaps) as default for all sprites
- Document sprite scale contract from ADR-008 in assets/README.md

Acceptance criteria:
- All directories created
- README.md documents conventions with examples
- Godot import defaults configured for pixel art
- One sample asset in each directory category (can be 1x1 pixel placeholder)

title: Define color palettes and player colors
description:
Create and document the color palette system for the entire game.

Age cluster palettes (each is a set of 8-12 colors):
- Stone/Bronze Age: earthy browns (#8B7355), muted greens (#6B8E4E), terracotta (#C75B39), clay (#D4A574), bone white (#F5F0E1)
- Iron/Medieval Age: deeper greens (#3D6B3D), stone gray (#8C8C8C), steel blue (#4682B4), burgundy (#722F37), gold accent (#DAA520)
- Industrial Age: brick red (#A0522D), iron gray (#696969), smoke (#B0B0B0), amber (#FFBF00), coal black (#2C2C2C)
- Information/Singularity Age: steel blue (#4169E1), clean white (#F0F0F0), neon cyan (#00CED1), holographic purple (#9370DB), circuit green (#00FF41)

Player colors (high contrast, colorblind-considered):
- Player 1: Blue (#2E86DE)
- Player 2: Red (#E74C3C)
- Player 3: Teal (#1ABC9C)
- Player 4: Orange (#F39C12)
- Gaia/neutral: Gray (#95A5A6)

Terrain colors:
- Grass: #4A7C4A (base), #3D6B3D (shadow)
- Desert: #D4B87A (base), #C4A86A (shadow)
- Water shallow: #5B9BD5 (base), #4A8AC4 (shadow)
- Water deep: #2E5B8A (base), #1D4A79 (shadow)
- Forest floor: #3D5A3D (base), #2C492C (shadow)
- Mountain: #8C8C8C (base), #6B6B6B (shadow)

Create:
- Palette reference image (PNG swatch sheet) committed to assets/reference/
- Godot theme resource with player colors defined
- Document palette usage rules in assets/README.md

Acceptance criteria:
- All palettes defined with hex values
- Swatch reference image in repo
- Player colors pass WCAG AA contrast against all terrain types
- Palettes feel distinct per age cluster

title: Create Phase 1 placeholder UI assets and icons
description:
Create minimal UI assets so HUD development can proceed without final art.

Resource icons (32x32px each, simple geometric):
- Food: red apple circle
- Wood: brown log rectangle
- Stone: gray rock triangle
- Gold: yellow coin circle
- Knowledge: blue book square
- Population: white person silhouette

HUD panel backgrounds:
- Bottom panel: dark semi-transparent rectangle (#1A1A1A at 80% opacity)
- Minimap frame: dark border rectangle
- Resource bar: dark strip with slight gradient
- Tooltip background: dark with 1px border

Button states (64x32px):
- Normal: dark gray with slight bevel
- Hover: slightly lighter
- Pressed: slightly darker, 1px inset
- Disabled: desaturated

Cursor sprites:
- Default: standard arrow
- Move: boot/arrow pointing down
- Attack: sword/crosshair
- Gather: hand/pick
- Build: hammer
- Invalid: red X

Font selection:
- Choose 1 primary font for UI (readable at small sizes, free license)
- Choose 1 header/title font (more stylized, free license)
- Import as Godot FontFile resources with fallback chain

Acceptance criteria:
- All resource icons distinguishable at 32x32
- HUD panels render cleanly at 1920x1080 and 1280x720
- Cursor states are visually distinct
- Fonts render clearly at 12px, 16px, and 24px sizes

title: Build throwaway isometric feel prototype
description:
Build a quick throwaway prototype (separate scene, not production code) to validate the isometric feel before building real systems. This is a time-boxed spike — max 1 day of effort.

Prototype must answer these questions:
1. Does 128x64 tile size feel right at target zoom? Can you see enough of the map?
2. Does the camera pan/zoom feel responsive? What are good min/max zoom limits?
3. Is a villager at ~48px tall visible and selectable without squinting?
4. Does unit movement speed feel right? How many tiles per second is good?
5. Can you visually distinguish 3-4 different terrain types at game zoom?
6. Does the isometric click-to-world coordinate conversion feel accurate?

Build:
- Hand-place a 20x20 isometric tilemap with 3-4 terrain types using placeholder tiles
- Add a Camera2D with pan (WASD) and zoom (scroll wheel)
- Place 5-10 unit placeholders (colored circles)
- Click to select, right-click to move (basic, no pathfinding — just lerp to position)
- Isometric screen-to-world coordinate conversion for click targeting

Document findings in a short writeup:
- What tile size / zoom range felt good
- What unit speed felt good (tiles per second)
- Any surprises about iso coordinate math
- Screenshots at min zoom, default zoom, max zoom

This prototype is explicitly throwaway — it does NOT need tests, lint, or coverage. It informs ADR decisions before real implementation begins.

Acceptance criteria:
- Can pan and zoom around a 20x20 iso map
- Can click to select and right-click to move a unit
- Findings documented with specific numbers (zoom range, speed, etc.)
- Prototype clearly marked as throwaway (separate directory or branch)

title: ADR-004: Historical Civilizations
description: Three civilizations: Mesopotamia (builders, +15% build speed), Rome (military, +10% military stats), Polynesia (naval, +20% naval speed). Each with unique units, buildings, and techs.

title: ADR-005: Age Progression System
description: Seven ages: Stone → Bronze → Iron → Medieval → Industrial → Information → Singularity. Each unlocks buildings, units, techs. Advancing requires resources + prerequisite buildings. Singularity endgame: GPU Foundry → Transformer Lab → AGI Core.

title: ADR-007: Quality Pipeline — Test-Driven Game Development
description:
Every system in Roots of Reason must be testable and tested before merge. The CI pipeline is a first-class game system that enforces quality gates on every PR.

Decisions: (1) GdUnit4 as the unit/integration test framework (GDScript-native, JUnit XML output, CI-friendly). (2) Minimum 90% line coverage on all gameplay scripts (autoloads/, scripts/). Coverage enforced in CI — PRs that drop below threshold are blocked. (3) Static analysis via gdtoolkit (gdlint + gdformat) — zero warnings policy. (4) Headless scene smoke tests — every scene must load without errors in headless mode. (5) Playability integration tests — automated scenarios that simulate real gameplay headless and assert game state correctness. (6) Screenshot regression testing — capture UI screenshots in CI and compare against baselines. (7) Performance budgets — frame time benchmarks for key scenarios, CI fails if benchmarks regress beyond 15%. (8) Export validation — CI builds macOS and Windows exports and verifies they launch.

Consequences: High confidence in every merge. Slower CI runs (~5-10 min) but catches regressions immediately. Test infrastructure built once, pays dividends on every subsequent epic. 90% coverage enforces testable architecture. Screenshot tests catch UI regressions that unit tests miss.

title: Epic 11: Naval & Vehicles
description: Water tiles, coastlines, dock building, ship types (Fishing, Transport, War Galley, Cannon Ship), embarking/disembarking, later-age land vehicles (Tanks, Artillery).

title: Water tiles and coastline generation
description: Water terrain tiles with coastline transitions. Generate rivers and ocean/lakes during map gen. Shore tiles where land meets water. Ships can only move on water tiles. Land units cannot cross water without transport.

title: Dock building and ship production
description: Dock: must be placed on shore tile (adjacent to water). Produces ships. Acts as drop-off for fishing boats. Has its own build queue. Requires access to water.

title: Ship types: Fishing Boat, Transport, War Galley, Cannon Ship
description: Fishing Boat (gathers fish), Transport (carries up to 10 land units), War Galley (ranged attack ship, Bronze Age), Cannon Ship (heavy attack ship, Industrial Age). Each with stats and upgrade path.

title: Embarking and disembarking land units
description: Land units can board Transport ships at shore. Right-click transport to board, right-click shore to disembark. Units are hidden while aboard. Transport sinks = all units die. Loading/unloading takes time.

title: Later-age land vehicles: Tanks and Artillery
description: Industrial Age+: Tank (heavy armor, fast, anti-infantry), Artillery (extreme range, anti-building, slow, minimum range). Produced at Factory building. These replace cavalry and siege in later ages.

title: Epic 13: UI & HUD
description: Resource bar, minimap, unit/building info panel, command panel, in-game menus, main menu and lobby screen.

title: Resource bar (top of screen)
description: Top bar showing all 5 resources with icons and amounts. Population counter (current/max). Age indicator. Real-time updates. Compact layout that doesn't obstruct gameplay.

title: Minimap (bottom-left)
description: Minimap showing terrain, fog of war, unit positions (color-coded by player), buildings. Click minimap to pan camera. Show camera viewport rectangle. Right-click minimap to move selected units.

title: Unit and building info panel (bottom-center)
description: Bottom-center panel showing selected unit/building info: portrait, name, HP bar, stats, current action. For buildings: production queue, rally point. For multiple selection: grid of unit icons with HP bars.

title: Command panel (bottom-right)
description: Bottom-right grid of command buttons. Context-sensitive: shows available actions for selected unit/building. Build menu for villagers, unit production for military buildings, formation buttons for groups. Hotkey labels on buttons.

title: In-game menus: save, load, settings, quit
description: Escape key opens pause menu overlay. Options: Resume, Save Game, Load Game, Settings (audio, video, keybinds), Quit to Menu, Quit to Desktop. Settings persist between sessions.

title: Main menu and game lobby screen
description: Main menu: Single Player, Settings, Credits, Quit. Single Player lobby: map size, map type, number of opponents, AI difficulty, civilization selection. Start Game button launches game with configured settings.

title: Epic 10: Civilizations
description: Civilization data model, Mesopotamia (+15% build, Ziggurat, Immortal Guard), Rome (+10% military, Colosseum, Legionnaire), Polynesia (+20% naval, Marae, War Canoe), selection screen.

title: Civilization data model and bonus system
description: Create civ data structure: name, description, bonuses (stat multipliers), unique_unit, unique_building, unique_techs, starting_bonuses. Load from JSON data files. Apply bonuses through modifier system.

title: Mesopotamia: Ziggurat, Immortal Guard, builder bonuses
description: Mesopotamia: +15% building construction speed. Unique building: Ziggurat (replaces Library, +50% Knowledge generation). Unique unit: Immortal Guard (heavy infantry, self-heal). Unique techs: Irrigation (+25% farm output), Code of Laws (+10% all resource income).

title: Rome: Colosseum, Legionnaire, military bonuses
description: Rome: +10% military unit attack and defense. Unique building: Colosseum (morale aura, +5% speed to nearby units). Unique unit: Legionnaire (infantry with shield wall ability, +3 defense when stationary). Unique techs: Roman Roads (+15% unit speed), Testudo (+20% ranged defense).

title: Polynesia: Marae, War Canoe, naval bonuses
description: Polynesia: +20% naval unit speed. Unique building: Marae (culture building, reveals coastline on construction). Unique unit: War Canoe (fast attack ship, can carry 5 units). Unique techs: Wayfinding (+30% naval LOS), Haka (+15% attack for 30s battle cry ability).

title: Civilization selection screen
description: Pre-game screen showing 3 civilizations with art, description, bonuses list, unique unit/building preview. Player selects civ before game starts. AI civs can be set or randomized.

title: Epic 8: Combat System
description: Attack-move, auto-targeting, melee vs ranged damage, armor types (rock-paper-scissors), siege mechanics, unit death, victory/defeat conditions.

title: Attack-move and auto-targeting
description: Attack-move command: unit moves to target location, engages any enemy in range along the way. Idle military units auto-target nearby enemies within aggro range. Prioritize: attacking unit > closest enemy.

title: Melee vs ranged damage resolution
description: Melee units must be adjacent to attack. Ranged units attack from distance. Damage = attacker.attack - defender.defense (minimum 1). Attack speed varies by unit. Ranged units have projectile travel time.

title: Armor types and damage bonuses (rock-paper-scissors)
description: Damage type system: Infantry strong vs Archers, Archers strong vs Cavalry, Cavalry strong vs Infantry. Siege strong vs Buildings. Bonus damage multipliers (1.5x). Creates tactical variety.

title: Siege mechanics and building damage
description: Buildings take 80% reduced damage from non-siege units. Siege units deal full damage to buildings but are slow and weak vs other units. Garrison units inside buildings for protection and arrow fire.

title: Unit death, corpse cleanup, and kill tracking
description: Units play death animation and leave corpse. Corpses fade after 30 seconds. Track kills per unit for stats. Free population cap on death. Play death sound effect.

title: Victory and defeat conditions
description: Defeat: all Town Centers destroyed. Victory: all enemies defeated, OR Singularity achieved, OR Wonder timer expires. Show victory/defeat screen with option to continue playing or return to menu.

title: Epic 7: Technology Tree
description: 7 Ages progression, age advancement costs, per-age techs, unique civ techs, tech tree UI viewer, Singularity age chain (GPU Foundry → Transformer Lab → AGI Core).

title: Age advancement: 7 ages with resource costs and prerequisites
description: Advance through 7 ages at Town Center. Each age requires resource cost (escalating) plus prerequisite buildings. Stone→Bronze: 500F. Bronze→Iron: 800F 200G. Escalating through ages. Advancement takes time.

title: Per-age technology research
description: Each age unlocks a set of technologies researchable at various buildings. Techs provide: unit stat bonuses, economic bonuses, building unlocks. Research costs resources and time. Cannot research techs from future ages.

title: Unique technologies per civilization
description: Each civilization gets 2 unique techs (one in Iron Age, one in Industrial Age). These provide civ-specific bonuses that reinforce their playstyle identity. Researchable at unique buildings or Library.

title: Tech tree UI viewer
description: In-game tech tree viewer showing all ages, techs, and dependencies. Scrollable/pannable tree layout. Color-coded: available (green), researched (gold), locked (gray). Shows cost and effect on hover.

title: Singularity Age: GPU Foundry → Transformer Lab → AGI Core
description: Final age unique chain: build GPU Foundry (Information Age), research Transformer Architecture at Transformer Lab, build AGI Core (massive cost). AGI Core completion triggers Singularity win condition. Each step has high Knowledge cost.

title: Epic 1b: Quality Pipeline & CI Infrastructure
description:
Build the CI/CD and testing infrastructure that every subsequent epic depends on. This is not optional polish — it is foundational. No gameplay code merges without passing quality gates.

The pipeline covers: unit tests, integration tests, coverage enforcement, static analysis, headless scene validation, playability smoke tests, screenshot regression, performance budgets, and export verification.

Must be completed alongside or immediately after Epic 1 (Project Foundation), before any gameplay epics begin.

title: Integrate GdUnit4 test framework with project
description:
Install and configure GdUnit4 (https://github.com/MikeSchulworking/gdUnit4) as the test framework.

Acceptance criteria:
- GdUnit4 addon installed in addons/gdUnit4/
- Test directory structure: tests/ mirroring scripts/ (e.g., tests/autoloads/test_game_manager.gd)
- Sample test file that passes: test instantiating a Node, asserting a property
- Can run tests locally via Godot editor and via CLI (godot --headless --script)
- Test runner outputs JUnit XML for CI consumption
- Document test conventions in CONTRIBUTING.md (naming, file layout, assertion style)

title: Performance benchmark suite with regression detection
description: Create automated performance benchmarks that detect regressions in CI. Scenarios: (1) Map rendering: 128x128 map, measure frame time with camera pan. (2) Unit pathfinding: 50 units simultaneously, measure completion time. (3) Combat: 100 units in melee, measure frame time. (4) Economy: 50 villagers gathering, measure per-frame cost. (5) Scene load time. Results saved as JSON artifacts. Compare against previous main branch run. Fail PR if any benchmark regresses more than 15%. Budget targets: map render <16ms (60fps), 100 units <16ms, scene load <3s. Framework created now, scenarios added as systems are built.

title: Set up GitHub Actions CI with Godot headless runner
description:
Create .github/workflows/ci.yml that runs on every push and PR.

Pipeline stages (in order):
1. Checkout + cache Godot binary
2. Import project (godot --headless --import)
3. Run gdlint (static analysis)
4. Run gdformat --check (formatting)
5. Run GdUnit4 tests with coverage
6. Export builds (macOS + Windows)
7. Upload build artifacts

Use official Godot Linux headless binary. Pin exact Godot version (e.g., 4.3-stable).
Cache .godot/imported/ for faster reimports.
Fail fast on lint/format, don't waste time on tests if code is malformatted.

Acceptance criteria:
- CI passes on clean main branch
- CI fails when a test fails
- CI fails when lint/format fails
- Build artifacts downloadable from Actions UI

title: Export validation — verify builds launch without crash
description:
CI builds macOS and Windows exports and verifies they run.

Requirements:
- Export macOS build (.app bundle or .zip)
- Export Windows build (.exe + .pck)
- For each platform: launch exported binary in headless mode, verify it starts without crash
- Validate that exported builds contain all expected resources (no missing .import files)
- Upload passing builds as GitHub Actions artifacts (downloadable)
- Use matrix strategy: one job per platform
- macOS: runs on macos-latest runner
- Windows: runs on windows-latest runner (or Linux + Wine for cost savings)

Acceptance criteria:
- Both platform builds exported successfully
- Both pass headless launch smoke test
- Artifacts available for download from CI run

title: PR quality gate — required checks and branch protection
description:
Configure GitHub branch protection and required status checks.

Requirements:
- Branch protection on main: require PR, require CI pass, require 1 approval (or auto-approve for solo dev)
- Required status checks: lint, format, tests, coverage threshold, export builds
- No direct push to main
- PR template (.github/pull_request_template.md) with checklist:
  [ ] Tests added/updated for changes
  [ ] Coverage threshold met
  [ ] No lint warnings
  [ ] Playability tests pass
  [ ] Screenshots updated (if UI changed)
- Auto-label PRs based on path (e.g., scripts/combat/ → 'combat' label)
- Status checks must pass before merge button is enabled

This is the enforcement layer that makes all other CI work meaningful.

title: Enforce code coverage threshold at 80% in CI
description: Configure GdUnit4 coverage reporting and enforce minimum thresholds. GdUnit4 generates coverage data for all scripts in scripts/ and autoloads/. Coverage report output as Cobertura XML or similar CI-parseable format. GitHub Actions step fails PR if below 90% line coverage. Coverage summary posted as PR comment. Exclude test files, addons/, and generated code from coverage calculation. Coverage badge in README. The 90% threshold applies to new/changed files AND overall project coverage.

title: Configure gdtoolkit for linting and formatting
description: Install and configure gdtoolkit (gdlint + gdformat) for static analysis. Create .gdlintrc config file with project conventions (max line length, naming rules). Create .gdformatrc for auto-formatting. gdlint runs in CI and blocks PRs with warnings. gdformat --check runs in CI and blocks unformatted code. Zero warnings policy: no suppressions without code comment explaining why. gdtoolkit is pip-installable.

title: Headless scene smoke tests — validate all scenes load
description: Create a test harness that instantiates every .tscn scene file in headless mode and verifies no errors. Script discovers all .tscn files in scenes/. For each scene: instantiate, add to tree, wait one frame, verify no errors in log. Catches: missing dependencies, broken node references, invalid resource paths, script errors. Runs as part of CI test suite. New scenes automatically included. This is the cheapest high-value test.

title: Playability integration test framework
description: Build a framework for automated gameplay scenario tests that run headless. Support: loading a test map (small, deterministic, no procedural gen), spawning entities at known positions, simulating player actions (select, move, gather, build, attack), advancing game time (simulate N ticks), asserting game state (unit position, resource count, building HP), deterministic replay (seeded RNG). Initial scenarios: (1) Villager gathers wood: spawn villager + tree, command gather, advance time, assert wood > 0. (2) Building construction: spawn villager, place building, advance time, assert building complete. Each subsequent epic adds integration tests for its mechanics. Framework runs in CI, tests complete in under 30 seconds.

title: Screenshot regression testing for UI scenes
description: Capture screenshots of UI scenes in CI and compare against committed baselines. Godot headless renders specified scenes to PNG at fixed resolution (1920x1080). Scenes: main menu, in-game HUD (with mock data), tech tree viewer, civ selection. Compare against baseline images in tests/baselines/ using pixel-diff (ImageMagick or similar). Threshold: >1% pixel difference flags PR for visual review. New baselines committed via PR. Diff images uploaded as CI artifacts. Catches: accidental UI layout breaks, font/theme changes, control sizing issues. Framework created now, baselines added as UI is built.

title: Epic 12: Win Conditions & Endgame
description: Conquest (destroy Town Centers), Singularity (build AGI Core), Wonder Victory (build + defend Wonder), AGI cinematic, post-game stats.

title: Conquest victory: destroy all enemy Town Centers
description: Player wins when all enemy Town Centers are destroyed. Defeat triggered when your last Town Center falls. Allow rebuilding TC from villagers if any survive. Check victory conditions periodically.

title: Singularity victory: build AGI Core
description: First player to complete AGI Core building wins Singularity victory. Requires: Information Age, GPU Foundry built, Transformer Architecture researched, massive resource cost (10000 Knowledge + other resources). Building takes 10 minutes game time.

title: Wonder victory: build and defend Wonder
description: Build Wonder (expensive, available from Medieval Age). Once complete, 10-minute countdown timer starts. If Wonder survives countdown, player wins. Other players alerted. Destroying Wonder cancels countdown.

title: AGI Singularity cinematic event sequence
description: When AGI Core completes: dramatic visual effect expanding from building, screen flash, all units on map pause, text overlay describing the singularity event. Transition to victory screen with unique singularity messaging.

title: Post-game statistics screen
description: After game ends, show stats: resources gathered, units produced, units killed, buildings built/destroyed, technologies researched, time in each age. Graphs over time. Compare all players side by side.

title: Epic 3: Procedural Map Generation
description: Isometric tilemap with terrain types, Perlin noise generation, resource node placement, starting locations, fog of war.

title: Isometric tilemap with terrain types
description: Create TileMap with terrain types: grass, forest, desert, water, mountain. Each terrain type has movement cost and resource availability. Use Godot TileMap with isometric mode.

title: Perlin noise terrain generation
description: Use FastNoiseLite (Godot built-in) to generate terrain. Multiple noise layers for elevation, moisture, temperature. Map these to terrain types. Configurable map size (small/medium/large).

title: Resource node placement on map
description: Place resource nodes during map gen: gold mines (mountains), stone quarries (hills), forests (wood), berry bushes/deer (food), fish (water). Ensure fair distribution relative to starting positions.

title: Starting location selection with fairness
description: Select starting locations for each player: ensure minimum distance apart, balanced resource access, no water-locked starts. Place initial Town Center and starting villagers at selected locations.

title: Fog of war and exploration
description: Three visibility states: unexplored (black), explored but not visible (dimmed), visible (full). Units reveal area based on line-of-sight stat. Previously explored areas show terrain but not enemy units.

title: ADR-002: Visual Style — 2D Isometric
description: Tile-based map with isometric sprites using 2:1 diamond tiles (128x64px). Classic AoE aesthetic, sprite-based units and buildings. Well-supported by Godot TileMap.

title: ADR-003: Single-player First
description: AI opponents via state machines and behavior trees. No networking code in initial release. Multiplayer deferred to post-MVP.

title: ADR-001: Game Engine — Godot 4
description: GDScript as primary language, C# for hot paths later. Godot 4 chosen for: open source, cross-platform (Mac + Windows), no licensing fees, strong 2D support, active community.
